title: Sam Darnold turns ball over five times as New England Patriots clobber New York Jets
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Drama surrounded Dallas this week but after demolishing the Eagles on Sunday night it's clear they're still the class of the division. That and more in Trysta Krick's Week 7 overreactions. USA TODAY

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The New England Patriots were already up 24 points.

It was the middle of the second quarter and the defense had just picked off New York Jets quarterback Sam Darnold for the second time in the red zone. At that point, it was New England’s third turnover, overall. The game, even this early on, was all but over.

But Patriots coach Bill Belichick called over his entire defense for a rare in-game meeting of the entire unit. They huddled around him on the bench. Belichick kneeled. Then, for about a minute and a half, Belichick drilled into the defense. The message was clear.

Clean it up.

The Patriots, before safety Duron Harmon leapt and cradled Darnold’s wayward pass, had committed three penalties in the series — a defensive holding, a defensive pass interference, and a roughing the passer — that gifted New York first downs.

When you’re one of the best teams in the NFL and dismantling your opponents the way New England is, it’s all about fine-tuning and the pursuit of perfection.

“It don’t matter the score on the board, he’s out there trying to make us better,” cornerback Stephon Gilmore told USA TODAY Sports. “That’s why he is who he is. That’s what makes him so great. We adjust and get better on the next play. He’s a great coach for a reason and I’m just happy that he’s my coach.”

JETS QB STRUGGLES: Sam Darnold said he was 'seeing ghosts' against Patriots

WINNERS, LOSERS: Aaron Rodgers now in MVP race

FOOTBALL FIX: NFL news delivered to your inbox

It was a rough night for Jets QB Sam Darnold against the Patriots defense. (Photo: Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Sports)

The Patriots embarrassed the Jets on Monday night, 33-0, to improve to 7-0 and remain one of the two undefeated squads in the NFL. And while the offense capitalized on New York’s six turnovers, five of them by Darnold, it is this defense that makes the squad a Super Bowl contender and arguably the strongest team in the AFC — if not the league.

New England relentlessly blitzed Darnold, making him uncomfortable, and clamped down on Jet targets with man coverage. They disguised their coverages, often flashing blitzes, only to drop back seven players.

Darnold finished the game 11 of 32 for 86 yards, no touchdowns, four interceptions, one fumble, and a QB rating of 3.6. The yardage and QB rating were career lows. The five turnovers were a career high.

“Those guys, man, they work hard, they have fun, and we feed off of that,” receiver Julian Edelman said. “It’s unbelievable to watch. We just try to do adjustments (on the sideline), and then you peek over and see one of the 15 or 17 playmakers they have making a play. It’s awesome to see. And it helps us.”

During the ESPN broadcast, Darnold wore a microphone that caught him saying, “I’m seeing ghosts” in reference to the pressure the Patriots brought.

It’s fitting, considering the Patriots linebackers have a nickname they’ve given themselves.

“Oooh, he did?” linebacker Kyle Van Noy said. “Oooh, man, that’s the boogeyman.”

Darnold was never comfortable. The disguising of the pressure often had him retreating, throwing off of his back foot. He also appeared to struggle making adjustments at the line of scrimmage, seeming to shift the protection of the offensive line in the wrong direction.

“It gets tough when they go with all their little guys and try to figure out who’s doing what and who’s covering who,” Jets coach Adam Gase said. “Who has the tight end? Who has the back? It can get tough sometimes.”

As Jets running back Le’Veon Bell lamented: “They had one more person than we could block.”

The Jets had 154 yards of total offense, went two of 11 on third-down tries, and didn’t convert either of their two trips into the red zone.

The Patriots, sitting at plus-175, have the largest point differential after seven games in the Super Bowl era. They’ve allowed 48 points, or 6.9 per game, which puts them on pace for 110 for the season. That would shatter the NFL record of 165 by the 2000 Baltimore Ravens.

What’s almost incredible is that of those 48 points allowed, 21 came off of turnovers that were returned for touchdowns.

New England’s secondary has forced 18 interceptions and has given up just one passing touchdown. Those 18 are most for a team through seven games in a season since the 1996 Packers had 20.

The criticism of the Patriots so far this season wasn’t so much about them, but about their schedule and the teams they’ve played. To be sure, the schedule has had its share of weaker opponents, including the 1-5 Jets twice. New England’s opponents so far this season have combined for a 12-32 record (.272).

The Patriots, however, don’t set their schedule. It’s not their fault that they’ve taken advantage of their opponents.

That will change in the coming weeks.

The Patriots will now face the Browns (2-4) and the Ravens (5-2) before their Week 10 bye, and then will play the Eagles (3-4), the Cowboys (4-3), the Texans (4-3), and the Chiefs (5-2). It’s a stretch that will define New England’s season and will determine whether the Patriot defense will truly be historic.

“It’s about the blueprint of coming out each week, each day in practice, putting in the work, studying film (and) getting on the same page,” McCourty said. “We’re talking about adjustments right after the coin toss of something that might come in a game. These guys are that locked in. We have to keep doing it because for the rest of the season, we’re going to get every offense’s best shot. They’re going to be ready to go. We’re not a surprise anymore, we just have to keep being locked in.”

description: The Patriots moved to 7-0 thanks to its championship-level defense's performance in a rout of the Jets on "Monday Night Football."
